key_insight: A meta-learning controller in O-RAN can quickly adapt handover policies per-location and per-user, combining Conditional and Traditional HOs to improve reliability while controlling signaling and resource costs.
problem_solved: Balancing the trade-offs between Traditional Handover (THO) and Conditional Handover (CHO) — e.g., failures, delays, signaling overhead and resource reservations — across diverse, large-scale mobile deployments.
method: Integrate a meta-learning agent into the O-RAN RIC that learns a shared prior over handover policies from many locations and tasks.
At deployment, perform fast adaptation (few-shot fine-tuning) to local mobility patterns to select or blend CHO/THO strategies that optimize reliability vs. signaling/resource use.
Evaluate policies using realistic countrywide mobility traces and network KPIs (handover success, latency, signaling volume) to guide online updates.
impact: Provides a practical blueprint for applying meta-learning to network control: enables ML practitioners to build controllers that generalize across environments and adapt rapidly in production O-RAN systems, improving QoE and operational efficiency without heavy re-training.
visual_elements: Schematic of O-RAN with RIC-based meta-learner controlling CHO/THO decisions
Side-by-side comparison diagram: THO vs CHO trade-offs (failures, delay, signaling, resource reservation)
Meta-learning workflow: meta-training across regions → fast adaptation at new cell sites (few-shot fine-tune)
Heatmap or map visualization showing region-specific policy selection and improvements in handover reliability
paper_title: Meta-Learning-Based Handover Management in NextG O-RAN
paper_authors: Michail Kalntis, George Iosifidis, José Suárez-Varela, Andra Lutu, Fernando A. Kuipers
